name: 勞維俊
objective:
課程橫跨英國文學的歷史，由中世紀到現代， 選讀英國文學史中最經典、最耐讀、可讀性最高的作品。務求由社會背境、歷史脈絡、和哲學思潮各方面理解作品。目標除了對英國文學史，不同文類（詩、戲劇、小說）和文學技巧有較全面的認識外，更可以提升理解其他文學作品的能力。
This course offers a directed sampling of a range of literary texts across the history of British literature, from the medieval to the modern period. Canonical works of different literary genres (poetry, drama, novel) will be discussed in relation to the social, historical and philosophical backgrounds. Upon completion of the course, participants should have a basic understanding of the history of British literature, and be able to identify their corresponding styles and literary devices, social and religious issues, and philosophical thoughts.
schedule:
Course Outline (subject to change):
1. Introduction　　: overview and examples, selected poems from:
Keats’ ‘Ode to Nightingale’
Wordsworth, ‘Lines Composed a Few Miles above Tintern Abbey’, and
Coleridge, ‘Kubla Khan, or, A Vision in a Dream. A Fragment’
Blake, ‘The Tyger’, ‘The Sick Rose’, ‘London’
2. Romantic poetry continued.
3-4. Gothic novel:
Robert Louis Stevenson, Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde (1886)
or Mary Shelley, Frankenstein; or, the Modern Prometheus (1818)
5-6. Victorian novel:
Dickens, Hard Times (1854),
or Emily Bront?, Wuthering Heights (1845-46) or Charlotte Bront?, Jane Eyre (1847)
7-8. Elizabethan Renaissance theatre
Shakespeare, Macbeth (1607)
9. Mid-term exam
10-11. Seventeenth century poetry
John Donne’s selected poems from Songs and Sonnets and Milton’s ‘Lycidas’
12-13. The eighteenth century
Satires: Extracts from the followings. 
John Dryden, Absalom and Achitophel (1681)
Alexander Pope, Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot (1735) 
Thomas Gray, ‘Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard’ (c.1746-50)
Samuel Johnson, ‘The Vanity of Human Wishes: The Tenth Satire of Juvenal Imitated’ (1749)
Samuel Johnson, ‘On the Death of Dr Robert Levet’
14-15. Modernist poem
T.S. Eliot, ‘The Waste Land’ (1922)
16-17. Modernist novel
D. H. Lawrence, Sons and Lovers (1913)
18. Final Essay due
scorePolicy:
The students are expected to have read the required primary texts before the lecture. Classes will be in the form of lectures and tutorials (2-hour lecture and 1-hour tutorial per week). Assessments include tutorial participations, group presentation, mid-term test, and essay writing.
Assessment:
Continuous Assessment:
Tutorial participation 　　10%
Group Presentation 　　20%
Mid-term test　　　　30%
Final Essay　　　　40% (drafts 20%, final 20%)
Total:　　　　　　　　100%
